00037 /**
00038  * \file error.h
00039  * \brief Declarations for \ref ErrorHandling Module
00040  *
00041  * $Source: /usr/local/Repositories/fcdmf/fclib/modules/error.h,v $
00042  * $Revision: 1.25 $ 
00043  * $Date: 2006/08/30 19:20:01 $
00044  */
00045 
00046 #ifndef _FC_ERROR_P_H_
00047 #define _FC_ERROR_P_H_
00048 
00049 #ifdef __cplusplus
00050 extern "C" {
00051 #endif
00052 
00053 // NOTE! If error.c ever created, move the group comment below to error.c
00054 /** 
00055  * \addtogroup ErrorHandling
00056  * \brief Data structures and routines to ease error handling.
00057  */
00058 
00059 /** 
00060  * \ingroup ErrorHandling
00061  * \brief If the return code is an error, print diagnostic and exit.
00062  *
00063  * \description
00064  *
00065  *    This is a helper macro to ease writing command line programs; it
00066  *    groups the test for an error return code with the handling: exit with
00067  *    the same value as the return code. 
00068  *
00069  *    Example usage: fc_exitIfError(rc) = 
00070  *
00071  *    "Exiting with error FC_MEMORY_ERROR (-2) at [program.c:276]"
00072  *  
00073  *    Sometimes this macro has compiling problems if it's used in an if-else
00074  *    block. To fix, surround the call with { }.
00075  *
00076  * \modifications
00077  *    - 05/25/04 WSK Created
00078  *    - 11/28/2005 WSD. Added printing of type of error (used to be silent).
00079  */
00080 #define fc_exitIfError(rc) \
00081   { \
00082     if ( (rc) != FC_SUCCESS ) { \
00083       fprintf(stderr, "Exiting with error %s (%d) at [%s:%d]\n", \
00084               fc_getReturnCodeText(rc), (rc), __FILE__, __LINE__);  \
00085       fflush(NULL); \
00086       exit(rc); \
00087     } \
00088   }
00089 
00090 /*
00091  * \ingroup ErrorHandling
00092  * \brief If the return code is an error, print message and exit.
00093  *
00094  * \description
00095  * 
00096  *    This is a helper function to ease writing command line programs; it
00097  *    groups the test for an error return code with the handling: print message
00098  *    and exit.  The message can consist of a format string and arguments, just
00099  *    like printf (but you don't need the trailing '\\n').  The message will be
00100  *    'Error: Your message'.  It will exit with the same value as the return
00101  *    code.
00102  *
00103  *    Example usage: fc_exitIfError(rc, "Mesh #%d incomplete", i) = 
00104  *
00105  *    "Exiting with error FC_ERROR (-1) at [program.c:75]: Mesh #2 incomplete"
00106  *
00107  *    Sometimes this macro has compiling problems if it's used in an if-else
00108  *    block. To fix, surround the call with { }.
00109  *
00110  * \modifications
00111  *    - 2003-NOV-11  WSK  Created
00112  *    - 05/25/04 WSK changed name and changed to include the error condition 
00113  *        checking. Also deleted this function's unnecessary counterpart 'warn'
00114  *    - 11/28/2005 WSD. Changed to a macro and added printing of type of error.
00115  */
00116 #define fc_exitIfErrorPrintf(rc, message, ...) \
00117   { \
00118     if ( (rc) != FC_SUCCESS ) { \
00119       fprintf(stderr, "Exiting with error %s (%d) at [%s:%d]: " message "\n", \
00120               fc_getReturnCodeText(rc), (rc), __FILE__, __LINE__, ##__VA_ARGS__); \
00121       fflush(NULL); \
00122       exit(rc); \
00123     } \
00124   }
00125 
00126 #ifdef __cplusplus
00127 }
00128 #endif
00129 
00130 #endif // _FC_ERROR_P_H_
